 PERFORM Centre (Prevention, Evaluation, Rehabilitation and FORMation/training) 
 Located on the south side of Sherbrooke Street at the Loyola campus, the PERFORM Centre makes a striking impression as it inclines towards de Maisonneuve Street. The main floor’s east side has aesthetic lines and windows that curve to create the image of an eye overlooking the centre’s landscaped entrance. The eye is emblematic of PERFORM’s clinical observations towards establishing better nutrition, improved rehabilitation methods, and healthier lifestyle choices for everyone. 
 The north-facing side is constructed entirely of windows to maximize natural light and connect the building’s interior with the outdoor landscape. The interior/exterior ambiance reflects the need for people to maintain a healthy balance with indoor and outdoor activities. Hallways are painted in warm yellow and orange tones for a sunny, welcoming effect. 
   
 PERFORM’s facilities include: 
 Cardio Pulmonary Evaluation  suite equipped to measure pulmonary and cardiac function through exercise stress testing 
 Clinical Analysis  suite with labs to examine the behavioural or metabolic changes in the health of participants at the molecular level 
 Nutrition  suite consisting of a state-of-the-art metabolic kitchen and teaching/dining area staffed by experienced dieticians and nutritionists, and used in conjunction with the Clinical Analysis suite for metabolic and absorption studies 
 Athletic Therapy (AT)  teaching clinic delivering prompt, professional care to faculty, students and staff, as well as the general public, while also offering Exercise Science students an innovative internship experience 
 Functional Assessment  laboratories equipped to measure motion range, flexibility, strength, balance, muscle action potential, water retention and neural activity 
 Research Imaging  suite enabling researchers to examine different areas of the body to see whether injuries or conditions might be improved with rehabilitation therapy 
 PERFORM also houses  Le Centre , which offers Concordia students, faculty, staff and alumni, as well as the public, the opportunity to improve their fitness in a unique conditioning and rehabilitation facility. The open space encased in windows from the building’s surrounding hallways reflects PERFORM’s trilateral focus on research, education and community engagement. 
   
 Leap , the public art embellishing PERFORM’s façade, was created by Montreal artist Adad Hannah. The large-scale, photo-based work on glass vibrantly depicts a series of 17 people engaged in various physical activities. Concordia students, faculty, and staff members served as models for the art to convey PERFORM’s goal of healthier living for everyone starting with the university’s community.
